topic.title: Bringing Down Your Cloud: Services Down Method

abstract.shortdesc: If you have a planned maintenance and need to bring down your entire cloud follow the steps below to safely do so. Be mindful that this method will bring down all of your services.

section.p: If you have a planned maintenance and need to bring down your entire cloud follow the steps below to safely do so. Be mindful that this method will bring down all of your services. If you wish to use a method utilizing rolling reboots where your cloud services will continue running then see .
If you wish to do any backups prior to these steps, visit the backup and restore pages first at .

section.title: Gracefully Bringing Down and Restarting Your Cloud Environment
section.p: You will do the following steps from your lifecycle manager.

ol.li: Log in to your lifecycle manager.
Gracefully shut down your cloud by running the hlm-stop.yml playbook: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts hlm-stop.yml
Shut down/restart or reboot your nodes.
Log back in to your lifecycle manager.
Determine the current power status of the nodes in your environment: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts bm-power-status.yml
If necessary, power up any nodes that aren't already powered up:cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts bm-power-up.yml
Bring the databases back up: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts percona-bootstrap.yml
Gracefully bring up your cloud by running the hlm-start.yml playbook:cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts hlm-start.yml

Pause for a few minutes and give the cloud environment time to come up completely and then verify the status of the individual services using this playbook:cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts hlm-status.yml

If any services did not start properly, you can run playbooks for the specific services having issues.
For example:
If RabbitMQ fails, run: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts rabbitmq-start.yml
You can check the status of RabbitMQ afterwards with this: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts rabbitmq-status.yml
If the recovery had failed, you can run: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts rabbitmq-disaster-recovery.yml
Each of the other services have playbooks in the ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible directory in the format of <service>-start.yml that you can run. One example, for the compute service, is nova-start.yml.
Continue checking the status of your cloud services until there are no more failed or unreachable nodes: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts hlm-status.yml
